snippet: The people who first designed the SAT decades ago wanted to identify a new elite based on brains rather than heredity, not necessarily to expand access to college.
abstract: News analysis; people who first designed the SAT in 1920s wanted to identify a new elite based on brains rather than heredity, not necessarily to expand access to college; latest College Board overhaul makes it more like its competitor, the ACT, in redefining merit as less about cleverness, and more about curriculum mastery.
lead_paragraph: The people who first designed the SAT decades ago wanted to identify a new elite based on brains rather than heredity, not necessarily to expand access to college.

headline.main: Then and Now, a Test That Aims to Neutralize Advantages of the Privileged
headline.print_headline: Then and Now, a Test That Aims to Neutralize Advantages of the Privileged

keywords.value: National Assn for College Admission Counseling
keywords.name: organizations
